speech.speaker: IAGO
speech.line: Here, stand behind this bulk; straight will he come:
Wear thy good rapier bare, and put it home:
Quick, quick; fear nothing; I'll be at thy elbow:
It makes us, or it mars us; think on that,
And fix most firm thy resolution.

speech.speaker: RODERIGO
speech.line: Be near at hand; I may miscarry in't.

speech.speaker: IAGO
speech.line: Here, at thy hand: be bold, and take thy stand.

speech.speaker: RODERIGO
speech.line: I have no great devotion to the deed;
And yet he hath given me satisfying reasons:
'Tis but a man gone. Forth, my sword: he dies.

speech.speaker: IAGO
speech.line: I have rubb'd this young quat almost to the sense,
And he grows angry. Now, whether he kill Cassio,
Or Cassio him, or each do kill the other,
Every way makes my gain: live Roderigo,
He calls me to a restitution large
Of gold and jewels that I bobb'd from him,
As gifts to Desdemona;
It must not be: if Cassio do remain,
He hath a daily beauty in his life
That makes me ugly; and, besides, the Moor
May unfold me to him; there stand I in much peril:
No, he must die. But so: I hear him coming.

speech.speaker: RODERIGO
speech.line: I know his gait, 'tis he.--Villain, thou diest!

speech.speaker: CASSIO
speech.line: That thrust had been mine enemy indeed,
But that my coat is better than thou know'st
I will make proof of thine.

speech.speaker: RODERIGO
speech.line: O, I am slain!

scene-body.stagedir: IAGO from behind wounds CASSIO in the leg, and exit

speech.speaker: CASSIO
speech.line: I am maim'd for ever. Help, ho! murder! murder!

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: The voice of Cassio: Iago keeps his word.

speech.speaker: RODERIGO
speech.line: O, villain that I am!

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: It is even so.

speech.speaker: CASSIO
speech.line: O, help, ho! light! a surgeon!

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: 'Tis he:--O brave Iago, honest and just,
That hast such noble sense of thy friend's wrong!
Thou teachest me. Minion, your dear lies dead,
And your unblest fate hies: strumpet, I come.
Forth of my heart those charms, thine eyes, are blotted;
Thy bed, lust-stain'd, shall with lust's blood be spotted.

speech.speaker: CASSIO
speech.line: What, ho! no watch? no passage? murder! murder!

speech.speaker: GRATIANO
speech.line: 'Tis some mischance; the cry is very direful.

speech.speaker: CASSIO
speech.line: O, help!

speech.speaker: LODOVICO
speech.line: Hark!

speech.speaker: RODERIGO
speech.line: O wretched villain!

speech.speaker: LODOVICO
speech.line: Two or three groan: it is a heavy night:
These may be counterfeits: let's think't unsafe
To come in to the cry without more help.

speech.speaker: RODERIGO
speech.line: Nobody come? then shall I bleed to death.

speech.speaker: LODOVICO
speech.line: Hark!

speech.speaker: GRATIANO
speech.line: Here's one comes in his shirt, with light and weapons.

speech.speaker: IAGO
speech.line: Who's there? whose noise is this that ones on murder?

speech.speaker: LODOVICO
speech.line: We do not know.

speech.speaker: IAGO
speech.line: Did not you hear a cry?

speech.speaker: CASSIO
speech.line: Here, here! for heaven's sake, help me!

speech.speaker: IAGO
speech.line: What's the matter?

speech.speaker: GRATIANO
speech.line: This is Othello's ancient, as I take it.

speech.speaker: LODOVICO
speech.line: The same indeed; a very valiant fellow.

speech.speaker: IAGO
speech.line: What are you here that cry so grievously?

speech.speaker: CASSIO
speech.line: Iago? O, I am spoil'd, undone by villains!
Give me some help.

speech.speaker: IAGO
speech.line: O me, lieutenant! what villains have done this?

speech.speaker: CASSIO
speech.line: I think that one of them is hereabout,
And cannot make away.

speech.speaker: IAGO
speech.line: O treacherous villains!
What are you there? come in, and give some help.

speech.speaker: RODERIGO
speech.line: O, help me here!

speech.speaker: CASSIO
speech.line: That's one of them.

speech.speaker: IAGO
speech.line: O murderous slave! O villain!

speech.speaker: RODERIGO
speech.line: O damn'd Iago! O inhuman dog!

speech.speaker: IAGO
speech.line: Kill men i' the dark!--Where be these bloody thieves?--
How silent is this town!--Ho! murder! murder!--
What may you be? are you of good or evil?

speech.speaker: LODOVICO
speech.line: As you shall prove us, praise us.

speech.speaker: IAGO
speech.line: Signior Lodovico?

speech.speaker: LODOVICO
speech.line: He, sir.

speech.speaker: IAGO
speech.line: I cry you mercy. Here's Cassio hurt by villains.

speech.speaker: GRATIANO
speech.line: Cassio!

speech.speaker: IAGO
speech.line: How is't, brother!

speech.speaker: CASSIO
speech.line: My leg is cut in two.

speech.speaker: IAGO
speech.line: Marry, heaven forbid!
Light, gentlemen; I'll bind it with my shirt.

speech.speaker: BIANCA
speech.line: What is the matter, ho? who is't that cried?

speech.speaker: IAGO
speech.line: Who is't that cried!

speech.speaker: BIANCA
speech.line: O my dear Cassio! my sweet Cassio! O Cassio,
Cassio, Cassio!

speech.speaker: IAGO
speech.line: O notable strumpet! Cassio, may you suspect
Who they should be that have thus many led you?

speech.speaker: CASSIO
speech.line: No.

speech.speaker: GRATIANO
speech.line: I am to find you thus: I have been to seek you.

speech.speaker: IAGO
speech.line: Lend me a garter. So. O, for a chair,
To bear him easily hence!

speech.speaker: BIANCA
speech.line: Alas, he faints! O Cassio, Cassio, Cassio!

speech.speaker: IAGO
speech.line: Gentlemen all, I do suspect this trash
To be a party in this injury.
Patience awhile, good Cassio. Come, come;
Lend me a light. Know we this face or no?
Alas my friend and my dear countryman
Roderigo! no:--yes, sure: O heaven! Roderigo.

speech.speaker: GRATIANO
speech.line: What, of Venice?

speech.speaker: IAGO
speech.line: Even he, sir; did you know him?

speech.speaker: GRATIANO
speech.line: Know him! ay.

speech.speaker: IAGO
speech.line: Signior Gratiano? I cry you gentle pardon;
These bloody accidents must excuse my manners,
That so neglected you.

speech.speaker: GRATIANO
speech.line: I am glad to see you.

speech.speaker: IAGO
speech.line: How do you, Cassio? O, a chair, a chair!

speech.speaker: GRATIANO
speech.line: Roderigo!

speech.speaker: IAGO
speech.line: He, he 'tis he.
O, that's well said; the chair!

speech.speaker: GRATIANO
speech.line: Some good man bear him carefully from hence;
I'll fetch the general's surgeon.
For you, mistress,
Save you your labour. He that lies slain
here, Cassio,
Was my dear friend: what malice was between you?

speech.speaker: CASSIO
speech.line: None in the world; nor do I know the man.

speech.speaker: IAGO
speech.line: To BIANCA What, look you pale? O, bear him out
o' the air.
speech.stagedir: CASSIO and RODERIGO are borne off
speech.line: Stay you, good gentlemen. Look you pale, mistress?
Do you perceive the gastness of her eye?
Nay, if you stare, we shall hear more anon.
Behold her well; I pray you, look upon her:
Do you see, gentlemen? nay, guiltiness will speak,
Though tongues were out of use.

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: 'Las, what's the matter? what's the matter, husband?

speech.speaker: IAGO
speech.line: Cassio hath here been set on in the dark
By Roderigo and fellows that are scaped:
He's almost slain, and Roderigo dead.

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: Alas, good gentleman! alas, good Cassio!

speech.speaker: IAGO
speech.line: This is the fruit of whoring. Prithee, Emilia,
Go know of Cassio where he supp'd to-night.
What, do you shake at that?

speech.speaker: BIANCA
speech.line: He supp'd at my house; but I therefore shake not.

speech.speaker: IAGO
speech.line: O, did he so? I charge you, go with me.

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: Fie, fie upon thee, strumpet!

speech.speaker: BIANCA
speech.line: I am no strumpet; but of life as honest
As you that thus abuse me.

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: As I! foh! fie upon thee!

speech.speaker: IAGO
speech.line: Kind gentlemen, let's go see poor Cassio dress'd.
Come, mistress, you must tell's another tale.
Emilia run you to the citadel,
And tell my lord and lady what hath happ'd.
Will you go on? I pray.
This is the night
That either makes me or fordoes me quite.

scene.title: SCENE II. A bedchamber in the castle: DESDEMONA in bed asleep; a light burning.

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: It is the cause, it is the cause, my soul,--
Let me not name it to you, you chaste stars!--
It is the cause. Yet I'll not shed her blood;
Nor scar that whiter skin of hers than snow,
And smooth as monumental alabaster.
Yet she must die, else she'll betray more men.
Put out the light, and then put out the light:
If I quench thee, thou flaming minister,
I can again thy former light restore,
Should I repent me: but once put out thy light,
Thou cunning'st pattern of excelling nature,
I know not where is that Promethean heat
That can thy light relume. When I have pluck'd the rose,
I cannot give it vital growth again.
It must needs wither: I'll smell it on the tree.
Ah balmy breath, that dost almost persuade
Justice to break her sword! One more, one more.
Be thus when thou art dead, and I will kill thee,
And love thee after. One more, and this the last:
So sweet was ne'er so fatal. I must weep,
But they are cruel tears: this sorrow's heavenly;
It strikes where it doth love. She wakes.

speech.speaker: DESDEMONA
speech.line: Who's there? Othello?

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: Ay. Desdemona.

speech.speaker: DESDEMONA
speech.line: Will you come to bed, my lord?

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: Have you pray'd to-night, Desdemona?

speech.speaker: DESDEMONA
speech.line: Ay, my lord.

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: If you bethink yourself of any crime
Unreconciled as yet to heaven and grace,
Solicit for it straight.

speech.speaker: DESDEMONA
speech.line: Alas, my lord, what do you mean by that?

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: Well, do it, and be brief; I will walk by:
I would not kill thy unprepared spirit;
No; heaven forfend! I would not kill thy soul.

speech.speaker: DESDEMONA
speech.line: Talk you of killing?

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: Ay, I do.

speech.speaker: DESDEMONA
speech.line: Then heaven
Have mercy on me!

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: Amen, with all my heart!

speech.speaker: DESDEMONA
speech.line: If you say so, I hope you will not kill me.

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: Hum!

speech.speaker: DESDEMONA
speech.line: And yet I fear you; for you are fatal then
When your eyes roll so: why I should fear I know not,
Since guiltiness I know not; but yet I feel I fear.

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: Think on thy sins.

speech.speaker: DESDEMONA
speech.line: They are loves I bear to you.

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: Ay, and for that thou diest.

speech.speaker: DESDEMONA
speech.line: That death's unnatural that kills for loving.
Alas, why gnaw you so your nether lip?
Some bloody passion shakes your very frame:
These are portents; but yet I hope, I hope,
They do not point on me.

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: Peace, and be still!

speech.speaker: DESDEMONA
speech.line: I will so. What's the matter?

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: That handkerchief which I so loved and gave thee
Thou gavest to Cassio.

speech.speaker: DESDEMONA
speech.line: No, by my life and soul!
Send for the man, and ask him.

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: Sweet soul, take heed,
Take heed of perjury; thou art on thy deathbed.

speech.speaker: DESDEMONA
speech.line: Ay, but not yet to die.

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: Yes, presently:
Therefore confess thee freely of thy sin;
For to deny each article with oath
Cannot remove nor choke the strong conception
That I do groan withal. Thou art to die.

speech.speaker: DESDEMONA
speech.line: Then Lord have mercy on me!

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: I say, amen.

speech.speaker: DESDEMONA
speech.line: And have you mercy too! I never did
Offend you in my life; never loved Cassio
But with such general warranty of heaven
As I might love: I never gave him token.

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: By heaven, I saw my handkerchief in's hand.
O perjured woman! thou dost stone my heart,
And makest me call what I intend to do
A murder, which I thought a sacrifice:
I saw the handkerchief.

speech.speaker: DESDEMONA
speech.line: He found it then;
I never gave it him: send for him hither;
Let him confess a truth.

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: He hath confess'd.

speech.speaker: DESDEMONA
speech.line: What, my lord?

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: That he hath used thee.

speech.speaker: DESDEMONA
speech.line: How? unlawfully?

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: Ay.

speech.speaker: DESDEMONA
speech.line: He will not say so.

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: No, his mouth is stopp'd;
Honest Iago hath ta'en order for't.

speech.speaker: DESDEMONA
speech.line: O! my fear interprets: what, is he dead?

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: Had all his hairs been lives, my great revenge
Had stomach for them all.

speech.speaker: DESDEMONA
speech.line: Alas! he is betray'd and I undone.

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: Out, strumpet! weep'st thou for him to my face?

speech.speaker: DESDEMONA
speech.line: O, banish me, my lord, but kill me not!

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: Down, strumpet!

speech.speaker: DESDEMONA
speech.line: Kill me to-morrow: let me live to-night!

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: Nay, if you strive--

speech.speaker: DESDEMONA
speech.line: But half an hour!

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: Being done, there is no pause.

speech.speaker: DESDEMONA
speech.line: But while I say one prayer!

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: It is too late.

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: Within My lord, my lord! what, ho! my lord, my lord!

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: What noise is this? Not dead? not yet quite dead?
I that am cruel am yet merciful;
I would not have thee linger in thy pain: So, so.

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: Within What, ho! my lord, my lord!

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: Who's there?

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: Within O, good my lord, I would speak a word with you!

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: Yes: 'tis Emilia. By and by. She's dead.
'Tis like she comes to speak of Cassio's death.--
The noise was here. Ha! no more moving?
Still as the grave. Shall she come in? were't good?--
I think she stirs again:--no. What's best to do?
If she come in, she'll sure speak to my wife:
My wife! my wife! what wife? I have no wife.
O insupportable! O heavy hour!
Methinks it should be now a huge eclipse
Of sun and moon, and that the affrighted globe
Should yawn at alteration.

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: Within I do beseech you
That I may speak with you, O, good my lord!

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: I had forgot thee: O, come in, Emilia;
Soft; by and by. Let me the curtains draw.
Where art thou?
What's the matter with thee now?

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: O, my good lord, yonder's foul murders done!

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: What, now?

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: But now, my lord.

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: It is the very error of the moon;
She comes more nearer earth than she was wont,
And makes men mad.

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: Cassio, my lord, hath kill'd a young Venetian
Call'd Roderigo.

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: Roderigo kill'd!
And Cassio kill'd!

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: No, Cassio is not kill'd.

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: Not Cassio kill'd! then murder's out of tune,
And sweet revenge grows harsh.

speech.speaker: DESDEMONA
speech.line: O, falsely, falsely murder'd!

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: Alas, what cry is that?

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: That! what?

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: Out, and alas! that was my lady's voice.
Help! help, ho! help! O lady, speak again!
Sweet Desdemona! O sweet mistress, speak!

speech.speaker: DESDEMONA
speech.line: A guiltless death I die.

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: O, who hath done this deed?

speech.speaker: DESDEMONA
speech.line: Nobody; I myself. Farewell
Commend me to my kind lord: O, farewell!

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: Why, how should she be murder'd?

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: Alas, who knows?

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: You heard her say herself, it was not I.

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: She said so: I must needs report the truth.

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: She's, like a liar, gone to burning hell:
'Twas I that kill'd her.

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: O, the more angel she,
And you the blacker devil!

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: She turn'd to folly, and she was a whore.

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: Thou dost belie her, and thou art a devil.

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: She was false as water.

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: Thou art rash as fire, to say
That she was false: O, she was heavenly true!

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: Cassio did top her; ask thy husband else.
O, I were damn'd beneath all depth in hell,
But that I did proceed upon just grounds
To this extremity. Thy husband knew it all.

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: My husband!

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: Thy husband.

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: That she was false to wedlock?

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: Ay, with Cassio. Nay, had she been true,
If heaven would make me such another world
Of one entire and Perfect chrysolite,
I'ld not have sold her for it.

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: My husband!

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: Ay, 'twas he that told me first:
An honest man he is, and hates the slime
That sticks on filthy deeds.

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: My husband!

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: What needs this iteration, woman? I say thy husband.

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: O mistress, villany hath made mocks with love,
My husband say that she was false!

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: He, woman;
I say thy husband: dost understand the word?
My friend, thy husband, honest, honest Iago.

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: If he say so, may his pernicious soul
Rot half a grain a day! he lies to the heart:
She was too fond of her most filthy bargain.

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: Ha!

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: Do thy worst:
This deed of thine is no more worthy heaven
Than thou wast worthy her.

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: Peace, you were best.

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: Thou hast not half that power to do me harm
As I have to be hurt. O gull! O dolt!
As ignorant as dirt! thou hast done a deed--
I care not for thy sword; I'll make thee known,
Though I lost twenty lives.--Help! help, ho! help!
The Moor hath kill'd my mistress! Murder! murder!

scene-body.stagedir: Enter MONTANO, GRATIANO, IAGO, and others

speech.speaker: MONTANO
speech.line: What is the matter? How now, general!

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: O, are you come, Iago? you have done well,
That men must lay their murders on your neck.

speech.speaker: GRATIANO
speech.line: What is the matter?

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: Disprove this villain, if thou be'st a man:
He says thou told'st him that his wife was false:
I know thou didst not, thou'rt not such a villain:
Speak, for my heart is full.

speech.speaker: IAGO
speech.line: I told him what I thought, and told no more
Than what he found himself was apt and true.

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: But did you ever tell him she was false?

speech.speaker: IAGO
speech.line: I did.

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: You told a lie, an odious, damned lie;
Upon my soul, a lie, a wicked lie.
She false with Cassio!--did you say with Cassio?

speech.speaker: IAGO
speech.line: With Cassio, mistress. Go to, charm your tongue.

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: I will not charm my tongue; I am bound to speak:
My mistress here lies murder'd in her bed,--

speech.speaker: All
speech.line: O heavens forfend!

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: And your reports have set the murder on.

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: Nay, stare not, masters: it is true, indeed.

speech.speaker: GRATIANO
speech.line: 'Tis a strange truth.

speech.speaker: MONTANO
speech.line: O monstrous act!

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: Villany, villany, villany!
I think upon't, I think: I smell't: O villany!--
I thought so then:--I'll kill myself for grief:--
O villany, villany!

speech.speaker: IAGO
speech.line: What, are you mad? I charge you, get you home.

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: Good gentlemen, let me have leave to speak:
'Tis proper I obey him, but not now.
Perchance, Iago, I will ne'er go home.

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: O! O! O!

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: Nay, lay thee down and roar;
For thou hast kill'd the sweetest innocent
That e'er did lift up eye.

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: Rising O, she was foul!
I scarce did know you, uncle: there lies your niece,
Whose breath, indeed, these hands have newly stopp'd:
I know this act shows horrible and grim.

speech.speaker: GRATIANO
speech.line: Poor Desdemona! I am glad thy father's dead:
Thy match was mortal to him, and pure grief
Shore his old thread in twain: did he live now,
This sight would make him do a desperate turn,
Yea, curse his better angel from his side,
And fall to reprobation.

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: 'Tis pitiful; but yet Iago knows
That she with Cassio hath the act of shame
A thousand times committed; Cassio confess'd it:
And she did gratify his amorous works
With that recognizance and pledge of love
Which I first gave her; I saw it in his hand:
It was a handkerchief, an antique token
My father gave my mother.

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: O heaven! O heavenly powers!

speech.speaker: IAGO
speech.line: Come, hold your peace.

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: 'Twill out, 'twill out: I peace!
No, I will speak as liberal as the north:
Let heaven and men and devils, let them all,
All, all, cry shame against me, yet I'll speak.

speech.speaker: IAGO
speech.line: Be wise, and get you home.

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: I will not.

speech.speaker: GRATIANO
speech.line: Fie!
Your sword upon a woman?

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: O thou dull Moor! that handkerchief thou speak'st of
I found by fortune and did give my husband;
For often, with a solemn earnestness,
More than indeed belong'd to such a trifle,
He begg'd of me to steal it.

speech.speaker: IAGO
speech.line: Villanous whore!

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: She give it Cassio! no, alas! I found it,
And I did give't my husband.

speech.speaker: IAGO
speech.line: Filth, thou liest!

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: By heaven, I do not, I do not, gentlemen.
O murderous coxcomb! what should such a fool
Do with so good a woman?

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: Are there no stones in heaven
But what serve for the thunder?--Precious villain!

scene-body.stagedir: He runs at IAGO IAGO, from behind, stabs EMILIA, and exit

speech.speaker: GRATIANO
speech.line: The woman falls; sure, he hath kill'd his wife.

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: Ay, ay: O, lay me by my mistress' side.

speech.speaker: GRATIANO
speech.line: He's gone, but his wife's kill'd.

speech.speaker: MONTANO
speech.line: 'Tis a notorious villain. Take you this weapon,
Which I have here recover'd from the Moor:
Come, guard the door without; let him not pass,
But kill him rather. I'll after that same villain,
For 'tis a damned slave.

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: I am not valiant neither,
But ever puny whipster gets my sword:
But why should honour outlive honesty?
Let it go all.

speech.speaker: EMILIA
speech.line: What did thy song bode, lady?
Hark, canst thou hear me? I will play the swan.
And die in music.
Willow, willow, willow,--
Moor, she was chaste; she loved thee, cruel Moor;
So come my soul to bliss, as I speak true;
So speaking as I think, I die, I die.

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: I have another weapon in this chamber;
It is a sword of Spain, the ice-brook's temper:--
O, here it is. Uncle, I must come forth.

speech.speaker: GRATIANO
speech.line: Within If thou attempt it, it will cost thee dear:
Thou hast no weapon, and perforce must suffer.

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: Look in upon me then and speak with me,
Or, naked as I am, I will assault thee.

speech.speaker: GRATIANO
speech.line: What is the matter?

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: Behold, I have a weapon;
A better never did itself sustain
Upon a soldier's thigh: I have seen the day,
That, with this little arm and this good sword,
I have made my way through more impediments
Than twenty times your stop: but, O vain boast!
Who can control his fate? 'tis not so now.
Be not afraid, though you do see me weapon'd;
Here is my journey's end, here is my butt,
And very sea-mark of my utmost sail.
Do you go back dismay'd? 'tis a lost fear;
Man but a rush against Othello's breast,
And he retires. Where should Othello go?
Now, how dost thou look now? O ill-starr'd wench!
Pale as thy smock! when we shall meet at compt,
This look of thine will hurl my soul from heaven,
And fiends will snatch at it. Cold, cold, my girl!
Even like thy chastity. O cursed slave!
Whip me, ye devils,
From the possession of this heavenly sight!
Blow me about in winds! roast me in sulphur!
Wash me in steep-down gulfs of liquid fire!
O Desdemona! Desdemona! dead!
Oh! Oh! Oh!

scene-body.stagedir: Enter LODOVICO. MONTANO, CASSIO carried in a chair, and Officers with IAGO, prisoner

speech.speaker: LODOVICO
speech.line: Where is this rash and most unfortunate man?

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: That's he that was Othello: here I am.

speech.speaker: LODOVICO
speech.line: Where is that viper? bring the villain forth.

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: I look down towards his feet; but that's a fable.
If that thou best a devil, I cannot kill thee.

speech.speaker: LODOVICO
speech.line: Wrench his sword from him.

speech.speaker: IAGO
speech.line: I bleed, sir; but not kill'd.

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: I am not sorry neither: I'ld have thee live;
For, in my sense, 'tis happiness to die.

speech.speaker: LODOVICO
speech.line: O thou Othello, thou wert once so good,
Fall'n in the practise of a damned slave,
What shall be said to thee?

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: Why, any thing:
An honourable murderer, if you will;
For nought I did in hate, but all in honour.

speech.speaker: LODOVICO
speech.line: This wretch hath part confess'd his villany:
Did you and he consent in Cassio's death?

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: Ay.

speech.speaker: CASSIO
speech.line: Dear general, I never gave you cause.

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: I do believe it, and I ask your pardon.
Will you, I pray, demand that demi-devil
Why he hath thus ensnared my soul and body?

speech.speaker: IAGO
speech.line: Demand me nothing: what you know, you know:
From this time forth I never will speak word.

speech.speaker: LODOVICO
speech.line: What, not to pray?

speech.speaker: GRATIANO
speech.line: Torments will ope your lips.

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: Well, thou dost best.

speech.speaker: LODOVICO
speech.line: Sir, you shall understand what hath befall'n,
Which, as I think, you know not. Here is a letter
Found in the pocket of the slain Roderigo;
And here another: the one of them imports
The death of Cassio to be undertook
By Roderigo.

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: O villain!

speech.speaker: CASSIO
speech.line: Most heathenish and most gross!

speech.speaker: LODOVICO
speech.line: Now here's another discontented paper,
Found in his pocket too; and this, it seems,
Roderigo meant to have sent this damned villain;
But that belike Iago in the interim
Came in and satisfied him.

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: O the pernicious caitiff!
How came you, Cassio, by that handkerchief
That was my wife's?

speech.speaker: CASSIO
speech.line: I found it in my chamber:
And he himself confess'd but even now
That there he dropp'd it for a special purpose
Which wrought to his desire.

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: O fool! fool! fool!

speech.speaker: CASSIO
speech.line: There is besides in Roderigo's letter,
How he upbraids Iago, that he made him
Brave me upon the watch; whereon it came
That I was cast: and even but now he spake,
After long seeming dead, Iago hurt him,
Iago set him on.

speech.speaker: LODOVICO
speech.line: You must forsake this room, and go with us:
Your power and your command is taken off,
And Cassio rules in Cyprus. For this slave,
If there be any cunning cruelty
That can torment him much and hold him long,
It shall be his. You shall close prisoner rest,
Till that the nature of your fault be known
To the Venetian state. Come, bring him away.

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: Soft you; a word or two before you go.
I have done the state some service, and they know't.
No more of that. I pray you, in your letters,
When you shall these unlucky deeds relate,
Speak of me as I am; nothing extenuate,
Nor set down aught in malice: then must you speak
Of one that loved not wisely but too well;
Of one not easily jealous, but being wrought
Perplex'd in the extreme; of one whose hand,
Like the base Indian, threw a pearl away
Richer than all his tribe; of one whose subdued eyes,
Albeit unused to the melting mood,
Drop tears as fast as the Arabian trees
Their medicinal gum. Set you down this;
And say besides, that in Aleppo once,
Where a malignant and a turban'd Turk
Beat a Venetian and traduced the state,
I took by the throat the circumcised dog,
And smote him, thus.

speech.speaker: LODOVICO
speech.line: O bloody period!

speech.speaker: GRATIANO
speech.line: All that's spoke is marr'd.

speech.speaker: OTHELLO
speech.line: I kiss'd thee ere I kill'd thee: no way but this;
Killing myself, to die upon a kiss.

scene-body.stagedir: Falls on the bed, and dies

speech.speaker: CASSIO
speech.line: This did I fear, but thought he had no weapon;
For he was great of heart.

speech.speaker: LODOVICO
speech.line: To IAGO O Spartan dog,
More fell than anguish, hunger, or the sea!
Look on the tragic loading of this bed;
This is thy work: the object poisons sight;
Let it be hid. Gratiano, keep the house,
And seize upon the fortunes of the Moor,
For they succeed on you. To you, lord governor,
Remains the censure of this hellish villain;
The time, the place, the torture: O, enforce it!
Myself will straight aboard: and to the state
This heavy act with heavy heart relate.
